title: Active Inference in Neuroscience and Perception
description: Application of Active Inference to understanding brain function, perception, and neural processing.
learning_objectives: Understand how Active Inference explains brain function
Apply predictive coding to perceptual processes
Analyze neural implementations of Active Inference

content.overview: Active Inference provides a unifying framework for understanding brain function. It explains how the brain minimizes free energy through hierarchical predictive coding, unifying perception, action, and learning.

neural_implementation.cortical_hierarchy: Different cortical areas implement different levels of hierarchy
neural_implementation.learning: Synaptic plasticity reduces free energy over time

perception_and_attention.visual_perception: Hierarchical processing from V1 to IT cortex

motor_control.inverse_models: Inferring motor commands from desired outcomes
motor_control.sensorimotor_integration: Coordination of sensory and motor systems

case_studies.name: Visual Object Recognition
case_studies.mechanism: Hierarchical predictive coding in visual cortex

case_studies.name: Motor Control and Learning
case_studies.description: How the brain learns and controls movements
case_studies.mechanism: Internal forward models predict sensory consequences
case_studies.experimental_tests: Adaptation to force fields, visuomotor rotation

practical_examples.name: EEG Prediction Error Analysis
practical_examples.description: Analyzing EEG data to test predictive coding hypotheses
practical_examples.research_question: Do prediction errors elicit stronger neural responses?

implementation.analysis: Event-related potentials (ERPs) for expected vs unexpected stimuli
implementation.prediction: Unexpected stimuli should elicit larger N2/P3 components
implementation.active_inference_interpretation: Larger responses reflect higher prediction errors

key_steps: Statistical testing of prediction error effects

practical_examples.interpretation: Results supporting predictive coding would show systematic differences in neural responses to expected vs unexpected stimuli

practical_examples.name: fMRI Effective Connectivity
practical_examples.description: Testing hierarchical predictive coding using dynamic causal modeling
practical_examples.research_question: Does visual cortex show hierarchical prediction error signaling?

implementation.data: fMRI during visual stimulation with predictable sequences
implementation.model: Dynamic causal model with hierarchical structure
implementation.predictions: Precision on top-down connections, prediction errors on bottom-up

key_steps: Preprocess fMRI data and extract time series
Compare models with different connectivity patterns

practical_examples.interpretation: Effective connectivity patterns revealing top-down prediction and bottom-up error signaling would support Active Inference

practical_examples.name: Neural Decoding with Active Inference
practical_examples.description: Using Active Inference to decode intended movements from neural activity
practical_examples.research_question: Can Active Inference improve neural decoding performance?

implementation.data: Neural recordings from motor cortex during movement tasks
implementation.inference: Invert model to decode intended movement from neural activity
implementation.comparison: Compare decoding accuracy with traditional methods

code_example.framework: PyTorch or TensorFlow for neural networks
key_steps: Train generative model on neural-movement pairs
Evaluate decoding accuracy on held-out data

practical_examples.interpretation: Active Inference framework may provide better decoding by incorporating uncertainty and hierarchical structure

experimental_predictions.learning_effects: Changes in predictive responses with experience
experimental_predictions.pathology: Disrupted predictive coding in mental disorders

interactive_exercises.description: Design experiments to test Active Inference predictions
interactive_exercises.predictions: Specific neural responses predicted by theory

clinical_applications.psychiatry: Understanding mental disorders as inference problems
clinical_applications.rehabilitation: Therapy based on restoring predictive function

future_directions.neural_imaging: Advanced imaging of predictive coding dynamics

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference is just predictive coding
common_misconceptions.clarification: Predictive coding is one implementation of Active Inference
Active Inference operates at subconscious levels too
Brain works with approximate, uncertain predictions
